title: Before 15 July 2021, will Canadians Michael Kovrig and/or Michael Spavor leave China?
possible_answers: Yes, both Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor
preds: Wanzhou's extradition hearing to proceed without the admission of HSBC documents issued by order of a Hong Kong court; https://reut.rs/36x4oPy. As that is only due to start in August, the probability of PRC releasing either or both Michaels now looks to be absolutely zero. Huawei surely has PRC backing and influence and the Michaels are likely to be held as bargaining material for later in the year. Two, perhaps controversial questions in this saga; a) if the new PRC 'approach' and attitude in Hong Kong had not been the case, would the HK court have ordered the release of the documents? and b) how much pressure did HSBC come under since the company moved its HQ to Hong Kong?

No sign that something can change for Meng Wanshou in Canada:
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/meng-wanzhou-evidence-extradition-huawei-1.6097232

Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor were clearly arrested in retaliation for the arrest of Meng Wangzhou in Vancouver; their release will not occur without any sort of reciprocation from Canada regarding Meng Wangzhou, and even then remains exceedingly unlikely. Statements from Justin Trudeau indicate the Canadian government will not interfere in the extradition process, which is ongoing and faces repeated delays from Meng Wangzhou's defense team. The situation will not be resolved, and the two Canadians will not be released, before July 15 2021.

Try as they might, Meng Wanzhou's lawyers are attempting to get the judge in the extradition hearing to rule on the admissibility of evidence not normally applicable in extraditions hearings; https://bit.ly/36gZar7 & https://bit.ly/3jSJHWa / https://bit.ly/3hGVWTn. Some suggest that the 'new' evidence Meng's lawyers wish to submit proves that the US mislead the Canadians regarding HSBC and Huawei's Iranian operations. Thus, if the Canadian prosecution's case holds, i.e. the evidence is irrelevant to an extradition hearing and should be included in the US trial, then there is little likelihood of the release of the "two Michael's" before the closing date of this question. It appears that the judge is unlikely to rushed and will proceed with the extradition hearing  in early August.
Another question that should have been called a couple of months ago.  China has no incentive nor interest in releasing either, never have.

Bet unchanged, comments thread brought forward here: @Tolga thx for your question from two days ago in the other comment thread f. It's structure doesn't elicit a precise  yes/no answer and could be used in different ways to be a platform for someones screed.  So I'll dodge the question and just re-state my past screed and look for outside attacks to convince me of further adjustment. I'm clearly in the weeds from the crowd and have been for some time. China has much to gain by making concessions and so does USA in this matter: A Jewel of Chinese society was plucked from them... "ordered" by USA "via" Canada (to honour the terms of an extradition treaty) based on info USA provided. The story on the veracity of the "basis" provided is murky.  Two days after the Jewel was plucked, two of Canada's small fry were tossed in the hoosegow on dubious charges with no consular access to begin, and little kindness since. This is China's approach to things shown plain. The Jewel is living very well in Vancouver and free to move around (with a bracelet on her ankle) throughout her trial. The Jewel is being heartily defended in a long drawn out court matter, in which the Jewel's defence has been given exceptionally wide leeway by the courts while the small fry rot in China. This is Canada's approach to things shown plain.  The world sees this plainly. Canada is in an impossible situation to bring about the return of their small fry.  USA and China both have much to gain.  1. USA "owes" Canada for having put them into this position. (there is noted "dubiousity" in the precision and intent by which USA ordered the Canadian grab in Vancouver and Canada has "possibly" been duped into it by eager apparatchiks of a past administration. 
2. China seeks the return of the Jewel. Side benefits: each side can make an important win to their individual i"close-in" interests by making this go away.  The question ends in 7 weeks. PLENTY of time remains for the "diplomacy" front to play out. Like the NordStream stepdown yesterday by USA to support its important relationship with Germany, these can  and often are "over" in a single press release.  Other GJO Players have followed the "trials" in Vancouver very closely and are wiser than I on the micro-dates and times the "process" of that holds. But I gather that there is some risk to the Question date in your eyes. I'd like to hear those details if they're readily reportable, thx.  @Anneinak @cafebedouin @Jayce @Francis_Urquhart I'd love your neighbourly thots in the event you're following this one. Thx.
Not much time remaining, relations appear to be worsening... and currently appear to be likely to continue to worsen for most of the rest of the century.

How long will they be held captive in China? 10 years? I don't think so. 5 years? Maybe.
So assuming a 15 % chance that both will be released in a particular year, we get:
0.85^2 = 72 % that they be there for at least two years (happened)
0.85^5 = 44 % that they be there for at least five years (in accordance with my assumption above)
0.85^10 = 20 % for >= 10 years (also feels also plausible)
0.85^20 = 4 % for >= 20 years (feels also ok, since 20 years seem unreasonable long) So 15 % * (2 / 12) = 3 % that both will be freed in the next two months.

Meng Wanzhou's legal team has been told by the court in Canada to prepare for the final stage of hearings starting on 3 August. However, it seems her legal team will again try and introduce more evidence to court in June. https://bit.ly/3oqecU1 /  https://reut.rs/3w52sIZ Is this a simple delaying tactic on the legal teams part or is something else at play in the background which is not coming together as possibly initially thought or planned? US / PRC relations do not seem to be warming at all and there are no apparent signs of a deal being done. If anything, the two leaders, Biden and Xi jinping seem determined to show their 'strength' to their respective countries  which may not be conducive to improving relations. @sebawi / @SE_Meyer

I know none of you believe me. And I'm a Canuck, so impossible for me not to have *some* bias... BUT All along I've said this is an inconsequential thing for China to make go away, IF they get some stuff in return, primarily from USA. 
Their perfect win is a stepdown from the Meng Manzhou/Vancouver airport "extradition" stand-off, form which the Canadians were nabbed. With 60 days to go, today's little (BIG) story is in that realm:  HEADLINE: China News: U.S. will remove Xiaomi from blacklist, reversing jab by Trump https://www.reuters.com/world/china/us-defense-department-xiaomi-agree-resolve-litigation-court-filing-2021-05-12/  Lots of time to smooth this through. Biden is not a showman like Trump was. The NEW State Department and DOJ are more measured in their efforts/approach...  I reduced my bet confidence long ago, because the crowd is SO certain they'll stay in the hoosegow..., so making no changes in the bet... but you'll all owe me a beer when they get released :) Go Canucks!

Continues to be low probability.  The fact that their trial will not begin until August supports low probability by July 15th.  Maintaining current forecast to account for possible unforeseen break throughs.

From Aljazeera: “CBC News reported on Wednesday that Associate Chief Justice Heather Holmes granted the defence’s request and agreed to adjourn the case until the beginning of August.” Low likelihood China will release the two Michaels before then. OTOH, does anyone have a good list of foreign prisoners in China and how long they were held? For US citizens, there are two mentioned here. https://www.google.ca/amp/s/amp.cnn.com/cnn/2020/06/25/asia/us-china-detention-li-kai-intl-hnk/index.html One was deported after 2 years, another after 5. Kai Li, detained in 2016, is still imprisoned.
Kovrig and Spavor will certainly not be exonerated in a Chinese court, and there is currently no leverage to force their release.

No hearings before 15 august... in french, it said the court sais yes:
https://globalnews.ca/news/7776299/judge-request-delay-meng-extradition-case/
Never say never, but highly unlikely for a number of reasons.  Mainly China has no reason to negotiate with the United States, who's involvement has almost certainly complicated their release.

Meng's Canadian lawyers, as mentioned previously, have applied to the BC Supreme Court for a delay in the extradition proceedings scheduled to begin on 26 April, so they can review documents released by HSBC in Hong Kong and US. The Crown makes, what appears to me, to be a valid counter argument that Meng's lawyers are attempting to enter trial like proceedings rather than addressing the issue of the extradition as required in Canadian law. See https://bit.ly/3tz8wZw  If the documents released by HSBC are so meaningful, I suggest HSBC has made some sort of arrangement with the relevant PRC authorities. That still leaves the question as to whether HSBC is still a target for the SEC and it's delayed prosecution agreement in US? Thus, IMO, if the Canadian Court approves the delay, the next stage will be interesting in determining this question. However, if the Canadian Court rejects the delay appeal we may also have an answer in the next few weeks. For now, I retain my current position and will continue to monitor this.

Huawei Improperly Helping CFO Meng Fight Extradition, U.S. Says - Bloomberg
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-04-15/huawei-improperly-helping-cfo-meng-fight-extradition-u-s-says
Thu, 15 Apr 2021 21:53:24 GMT

The process of Meng's extradition trial in Canada could be drawn out beyond 15 May, the originally scheduled end date, as a result of a statement by US Federal Prosecutors that Huawei's lawyers are using embargoed information from the US criminal case in their defence of her extradition trial; https://bloom.bg/3wWQKBo. Or perhaps the Canadian judge will exclude that information, under advisement from US prosecutors, and continue with the current schedule. Either way, it is feasible that China proclaims that US & Canada are colluding in order to ensure Meng's extradition. In that case, in the short term, pending the final verdict in the extradition trial, the publicatiuon of the verdicts and potential subsequent release of the two Michaels seems unlikely within the  time frame of the question. Also noteworthy, thanks to @Jean-luc-Nadeau (https://bit.ly/2Qy7H4q), is the proposed application for adjournment of the last 3 weeks of the extradition trial by Meng's lawyers (https://bit.ly/32kNPV4). This could potentially hint at two or more outcomes; a deal has been agreed in the background and will be announced soon  for Meng's transfer to US? or for Meng's release to return to China? or possibly as @Jean-luc-Nadeau suggests, more delays are inevitable? Monday's application in Canada may hint at what is to follow. However, as @Mark_T pointed out,(https://bit.ly/3dtkSgd), relations between US & China have deteriorated in recent times. Hence, on the face of it, a deal seems unlikely. But perhaps a deal on this issue could break the downward spiral of the two superpowers' relations and reset the tone to move forward while at the same time, give Canada a bit of a reprieve? For the time being, I'll hold my long held position until I see anything more convincing.

More delays to come, and the decision can take a lot of time too.
https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/huawei-meng-adjournment-application-1.5991111

Lost of very useful and well-scoped research by @bh4eh here (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1262849) that all have the potential to tilt the field on this one. Combined with the escalation in US v China tensions around Taiwan [1] (which I think can be read as China flexing in front of a new President and testing the new administration's response), @bh4eh 's points all indicate a potential narrowing of the window for diplomatic solutions for the two Michaels. That said...the Meng Wanzhow extradition trial is due to wrap in mid May 21 (pending appeals), and may still represent an opportunity for a "back room" diplomatic off ramp for both the US government and Canada on the sticky issue of the Huawei CEO conundrum that they inherited from the diplomatic lump hammer that was the previous administration. A release of the two Michaels following on the back of a failed extradition proceeding for Meng is still possible (even with convictions in the kangaroo closed Court proceedings) as part of China's consistently Janus like behaviour (trade and economic ties one minute, sabre rattling and shows of strength the next). That said, relations across all involved parties have steadily degraded over the last two months and the hot rhetoric of this moment makes a climb down by July this year politically painful for any side (being read as it would as a capitulation to the other side's strength).  Whilst I see it likely that the Michaels and Meng Wanzhou will both be released back to their respective countries within days of each other within the next 12 - 18 months I can't see it happening in the next 3 months with the tone and tenor of current discourse. The only remaining opening seems to be the extradition hearing outcomes in May being used by one side or the other as a politically expedient off ramp (see rationale here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1229061) and the window for that also seems to have narrowed. with the time for this question ticking down steadily the likelihood of this resolving before July seems increasingly low. [1] https://edition.cnn.com/videos/world/2021/04/13/china-military-taiwan-biden-xi-jinping-culver-pkg-intl-ldn-vpx.cnn

It appears that HSBC & Huawei / Meng have reached an agreement in Hong Kong about the release of HSBC documents that could aid Meng in her fight against extradition to USA from Canada, - https://bit.ly/32bcZp2, albeit those documents may incriminate & expose HSBC to US sanction. I am surprised HSBC has agreed particularly considering that the UK courts sided with HSBC. Although we do not know the extent of the agreement in smells to me though HSBC is either under pressure in HK or attempting appease China. I suspect the former. Will this apparent step forward in Meng's case in Canada be of any use to the two Michaels? I suspect there is more to this than meets the eye and there is the possibility of a backroom deal being put in place.  In time for this question to resolve? Possibly though I am not convinced. All the necessary pieces have to be put in place and the US may well be reluctant to play ball. That said, Biden's administration may view this as an opportunity to appease Xi / China in some way after the rather terse meeting a few weeks ago. Equally, as France 24 notes (https://bit.ly/3tiplri) Meng's extradition trail is scheduled to end in mid-May, barring any appeals. Which is likely unless a backroom deal has been concluded. It's very possible IMO that the two Michaels' verdicts in their recent trail may be released around the time of the end of Meng's trial depending on the verdict in Canada. Or, shortly thereafter; https://bit.ly/3a72lEg. This article also highlights that Canada may simply be a bystander in the US v China battle for supremacy. Complicating matters for Trudeau and the current Canadian government, whose relationship with China is at an all time low, apparently, is the nomination of the 2020 HSF prize winner; https://politi.co/329C7fR. That said, one assumes that the Canadian courts will not be subject to political pressure.

While there has been some 'talk' in Canada that the change of administration in US from Trump to Biden may prove beneficial to the two Canadians in custody in China simply because Biden has (apparently) made it clear that he will support allies in confronting China. That may be the case, however, the most recent comments by Blinken and Austin (e.g. https://reut.rs/3vyNw6G) on their tour of Japan and S Korea are certainly not 'friendly' towards China. Hence, IMO, China is unlikely to ignore and brush off these comments. Certainly not as far as internal consumption is concerned. That begs two questions; a) is Canada's hope misplaced and b) why has China, apparently quite suddenly, announced a) the trial of the two Canadians is expected soon and b) almost 24 hours later announced the trial will start tomorrow and is schedule for 2 days? 2 days is an incredibly short time for what is (in western terms) a complex matter. Equally, China's courts have a notoriously high conviction rate. Particularly in matters such as this. See https://bit.ly/3tCvgqS. Thanks also to @Jean-luc-Nadeau for his link in his forecast (https://bit.ly/3r0pvlo ) confirming the trial from another source. From what little information we have regarding the Chinese prosecution and the charges, I suspect the trial will lead to a conviction. Although the Canadian embassy has applied for 'permission' to attend the trial, as of writing, it's not clear if that's been granted. Hence, what will happen in court tomorrow and Monday is unlikely to be transparently reported. Hence, I am reducing my forecast as above. @sebawi & @SE_Meyer for info in case you've not seen this.

This is looking like Meng's lawyers  are throwing everything and the kitchen sink at the Judge in the ongoing extradition hearing and perhaps smacks of some desperation? See https://reut.rs/3cJXgSF and https://bit.ly/3vBnnnD. My perception is that the crux of the matter is whether Huawei's relationship with the Iranian company put HSBC at risk of breaking US sanctions and not whether HSBC was at risk of financial risk. I may be wrong but it appears that is not the focus of Meng's defence and I am inclined to think the defence are trying to change the focus of the trial and evade the core issue. See https://bit.ly/3vBnnnD If in fact there is an element of desperation and Meng's case is actually weak, the likelihood of of Kovrig and Spavor being released, or tried and released before Jul 15 looks to be fading.

The CCP is not subtle about this at all. They’re timing the two Michaels “trials” to Meng’s one: https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-canadians-michael-spavor-michael-kovrig-to-face-separate-chinese/ There’s some talk the Biden admin might back away, allowing for Meng to pay a fine and leave—and possibly resulting in the Muchaels’ return. That would be dependent on whether Biden can get away with it without looking too soft on China.

Meng Wanzhou's extradition hearing in the Canadian Supreme Court gets under way again today (https://bit.ly/30HJhYa). Meng and her lawyers have argued that they should be allowed to admit statements from Huawei employees to substantiate her case that she did not mislead HSBC. However, a Supreme Court Judge has ruled that such evidence it outside the remit of an extradition hearing and the case should proceed (https://bit.ly/3qQI37B). In theory, the current hearing is scheduled for 3 weeks and a decision is expected in May. That would be subject to approval from the relevant Canadian Minister. However, with the potential for appeal by either side, this could drag on past the completion date of this question. This and the recent Chinese 'statement' that Kovrig and Spavor are likely to face trial 'soon' weigh towards little likelihood, in my view, of eithers release within the time frame of this question. Apologies to @SE_Meyer  & @sebawi for the incorrect date in my last submission for the resumption of Meng's case.
Reports that both men will face formal trials in China in the coming months decreases chance of their release.  Decreasing by 2%

I'm not sure how to update to the news that the two Michaels are expected to "face trial soon". My intuition is that China will bring the Michaels to face trial no matter whether the intention is for them to leave or not. This would show the Chinese public that the Michaels' arrests were justified and were not reprisals for Meng's arrest. See the precedent of Kevin and Julia Garratt:
"Kevin, who had been moved to a prison after his first six months in detention, would have to wait until September of that year after a court ruled against him on charges of spying and stealing state secrets. Following the trial, he was deported back to Canada."

Thank you @Mark_T and @Okanaganopolis for the constructive pushback on my excessively long post. I’ve definitely been close to lowering my confidence and probability forecast - I still might, just mulling it over. Also, as a Canadian, I certainly hope I’m wrong! Based on your feedback, I agree my logic could be sharper for bullet (2). Specifically, I think it is fair that Canada can not ‘drop’ the case, but it is a different event for the USA to agree to a settlement with Meng / Huawei where the case is instead ‘resolved through normal course’. That would not be negotiating in a ‘hostage diplomacy’ situation, from the USA perspective. It also makes sense that the ‘end game’ for any USA administration is not exactly having Meng ‘behind bars’ in the States - it would be to levy a hefty fine on Huawei (I’m guessing substantially more than the $1B fine on ZTE), have both Meng and Huawei admit to wrongdoing, and potentially agree to some further operating constraints or discipline against the company. Canada’s situation may urge the USA to ‘hurry up’, so the Michael’s DO seem like the main reason this could all possibly happen before July.  It is really tough to predict the timing on some sort of settlement with Meng or Huawei - so I think where the logic tree  goes after that I would pose as open ended questions (as I have no particular expertise here, and I’m not a lawyer): - How independent is the DOJ from the White House in cases and negotiations like these?
- Would the USA ever come to a settlement with Meng /separate from/ a broader settlement with Huawei?
- If the USA instead returns Meng to China, how much leverage do they lose over Huawei?
- What sort of wrongdoing would Huawei and Meng need to admit do? Just fraud? Violating Iran sanctions? Stealing American technology?
- Would they agree to that?  Is it better to the alternative of denial of guilt and living in Vancouver?
- Is this really the best ‘front’ of the USA - China relationship for Biden to try to de-escalate immediately?
- If he did, especially so early in his administration, how would domestic media and opposing politicians react? What would be required for a settlement to be a ‘win’ politically? Huawei is really on the front lines of whether or not China is engaging in ‘fair play’ in global capitalism  - many many countries are opposing using Huawei hardware in new 5G networks due to national security concerns. All of which makes the path to a quick resolution a lot more murky. But it also could be announced in a week! Hah.  FYI - for reference, here are a couple other sources that are good content and have coloured my thoughts here: (1) Ray Dalio’s writing on the overall China - USA long term relationship - chapter 7 specifically https://www.principles.com/the-changing-world-order/#chapter7 (2) Maclean’s article about why negotiations are standard course https://www.macleans.ca/news/talk-of-a-deal-for-meng-wanzhou-raises-hope-and-a-lot-of-wishful-thinking/ To your specific question  about the statement by the VP - I agree, it does raise questions. The phrasing used about ‘doing everything we can’ is quite consistent with public statements by Trudeau over the past two years. My own overall analysis is more focused on the structural drivers of the situation, so I don’t want to be swayed too much by something that could be simply the new administration and Trudeau helping each other gain political ‘points’ with the media. That said - in 2-3 months, if Meng is returned to China and the Michael’s are released, I will definitely reflect back that I did not properly weigh this statement! Hah.

This is an incredibly complex situation - so if anyone disagrees with my logic, I would love to hear it! Sorry in advance for long post. I see the underlying cause-effect process of this prediction as being driven by three areas.  I am describing these areas in terms of "what you 'need to believe' in order to predict that the two Michael's will NOT be released before July 15th 2021" (1) There is no situation where China will release either Michael until Meng Whanzou is returned to China
(2) Neither Canadian prosecutors nor the Biden Department of justice will agree to a Deferred Prosecution Agreement or otherwise decide to drop charges, prior to July 15th 2021
(3) The current legal battle in the British Columbia court system will extend beyond July 15th 2021 - OR - the extradition process will result in Meng being sent to the USA Each of the areas above represent a 'layer' of uncertainty to this question - and is a complex situation. Here is my best assessment of the facts on the ground of each aspect (1) I think this aspect is fairly clear cut, and there is a very low probability of the Michaels being released without Meng being returned (less than 1% chance).  (2) This is a complicated one, which sent me down a rabbit hole of revising my prediction. My current train of thought here is that: (a) Meng Wanzhou was not arrested on some 'politicalized' charge by Trump - she/Huawei have been  under investigation for a decade - "Counterintelligence agents and federal prosecutors began exploring possible cases against Huawei’s leadership in 2010" - https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/14/business/huawei-meng-hsbc-canada.html (b) Meng Wanzhou was arrested for lying to HSBC (fraud) surrounding Iran sanctions, but ultimately she is a person of interest for the USA because of extremely serious national security related charges. This is not a case that the USA can afford to take lightly! - "American national security experts believe China has bolstered its economy — now the world’s second largest — by stealing corporate, academic and military secrets. Among the concerns is that Chinese telecommunications equipment could be used to spy on American citizens. " - Same NYT source as above (c) The way that China has engaged in 'hostage diplomacy' - i.e. detaining innocent Canadians in response to a legitimate 'rule of law' arrest of Meng is unacceptable to the international community, and has happened to other countries in the past (e.g. Australians) (d) 'Capitulating' to China  sets an extremely dangerous precedent for ALL Western/democratic countries. It shows China that 'if you detain our innocent civilians under fake charges, you can get what you want from us'. In fact, it ENCOURAGES more of the behaviour in the future.  (d - extra) EDIT: adding source from Trudeau here - "This week, a group of prominent lawyers, former parliamentarians and diplomats wrote to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau imploring him to allow the Justice Minister to use his legislated power to unilaterally end Ms. Meng’s extradition proceedings. ... Mr. Trudeau respectfully said he would not do that. He gave two reasons: Canada’s justice system must remain free of foreign and domestic political pressure; and Canada cannot signal to China and other counties that “all they have to do to get leverage over the Canadian government is randomly arrest a couple of Canadians.” - https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/editorials/article-justin-trudeau-says-he-cant-give-in-to-chinas-hostage-taking-hes/ (e) As such, a decision to politically over-rule the legal process of extradition is extremely short-sighted, and goes against all goals for democratic countries that try to promote the 'rule of law' (instead of authoritarian rule) (f) Biden's foreign policy approach of a 'Summit for Democracy' (collaborating as a unified front with democratic allies) clearly demonstrates how seriously he takes these issues (e) The WSJ report in December 2020 around DPA discussions is rumored to have been leaked by China as something CHINA is hoping for (or was proposing), and it is seen as an exceptionally rare and unlikely outcome (DPAs generally only apply to corporations, not individuals)  As a result, I see this as relatively low probability (<5%) that either Canadian or USA governments intervene in the court case before it has ended (3) This area is also a complicated, specialized area of the law, but there are a couple areas that make me think it is also a low probability (a) Dual criminality standard has already been reached - "In May 2020, the British Columbia supreme court justice Heather Holmes ruled on Wednesday that the alleged actions of Meng would be considered a crime in Canada – a key condition for extradition to proceed." https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2020/may/27/huawei-meng-wanzhou-canada-court-ruling-us-extradition (b) The base rate of avoiding extradition to the USA is 1 in 100 - https://financialpost.com/technology/the-odds-of-huaweis-cfo-avoiding-u-s-extradition-are-just-one-in-100 (c) The case is set to proceed in the BC Supreme Court from early March until the end of April. AFTER THAT POINT, it can be appealed by the losing side to TWO additional levels of court - the BC Court of Appeals and then the Supreme Court of Canada. This is an extremely long process, and this assumption alone could extend the timeline by over a year. https://www.bccourts.ca/about_the_courts/ (d) Here is a summary on how the extradition process works. https://www.justice.gc.ca/eng/cj-jp/emla-eej/extradition.html - It is currently in 'Phase 2 - Judicial'	 (e) "By opening multiple legal fronts, Meng’s team has all but ensured the tussle will last for years, with many experts believing the case is inevitably bound for the supreme court of Canada. " - Same source as above, The Guardian As such, I am sticking with the base rate of 1% here, and my combined probabilities amount to less than 5-10% chance the Michaels are released before this date, sadly. There are many complicated layers here that I think add a lot of uncertainty to the situation, though.

An extremely unfortunate situation. I agree with @thefonz . Until Meng Wanzhou is released and returned, the same will not be done for Michael and Michael. As such I think the real prediction here is 'is there a settlement for the Meng trial prior to 15 July 2021' (with enough time afterward for her to arrive and China and then China to release them). Based on this article https://www.cnbc.com/2020/01/10/huawei-cfo-meng-wanzhou-extradition-trial-explained.html there are three phases involved in the trial. One starting January 20th, a second one for June, and a third potential phase in September. The only way these protracted legal proceedings are avoided are that the judge sides with Meng AND there is no appeal, in the January proceedings (focused on double criminality standard) or June proceedings focused on due process during her arrest. The base rate for 'avoiding extradition from Canada to USA' is that 1% of people accomplish this. As such, I am going with a strong 90% probability that the Meng case is not fully sorted out by July 15th. Implicitly I am also assuming that the Biden administration does not choose to drop the charges in his first 5 months as president (to avoid looking 'soft on China'), or finding some other technicality which would result in her release and then the subsequent release of the Michaels. I am not a legal expert though. I highly doubt the Canadian government would accept one of them being returned but not the other, but putting at 1% as it is not entirely impossible they are sent home in a staged fashion. The Canadian 'two Michaels' appear to have been imprisoned in China in a tit for tat against the Canadian house arrest of Meng Wanzhou, the Huawei CFO who is wanted on a US extradition warrant on charges of breaking US sanctions against Iran - see https://bit.ly/3h5ObFM. The apprehension of Meng at Vancouver airport in December 2018 was followed nine days later by the 'disappearance' of Kovrog and Spavor. As one would expect, China refutes this view - see https://bit.ly/38r0dp3. However, this, https://bit.ly/3nEDo81, suggests otherwise. Meng has been fighting the extradition warrant for the past 2 years. There is some doubt whether or not the two Michaels have been charged and tried in court. Part of the confusion is because they have apparently been charged in PRC security laws as a threat to PRC national security. See https://bbc.in/38p7GoT and https://bit.ly/2KqXsw7. Some sources suggest that a 'deal' to release the two Michaels may be under discussion if Meng is released and returned to China - https://bit.ly/34yQH2m Meng's lawyers have out forward various arguments as to why she should not be extradited to US. The most recent of which appears to be 'grasping at straws' - https://bit.ly/2KooDHO. As it looks increasingly likely Meng will be extradited to US to be tried in US, I do not think it is possible for the two Michaels to be released imminently or within the time frame of this question.
